Eight years ago, nine congregants were shot and killed at Mother Emanuel Church — and the “Charleston Loophole” that allowed the murderer to buy a gun without passing a background check is still open.

I’m working to force a bill to the U.S. House floor to close this loophole.
If you use or threaten violence, you must be held publicly accountable — and others contemplating violence should be deterred by the stories like this one today.
One of the ways is demonstrating what happens when you make these threats. People get arrested, families are thrown into chaos, and this young man’s life will never be the same.

And earlier this month, antisemitic fliers were distributed in Hartland that compared Jewish people to pedophiles. It seems like not a month goes by that I’m not on the phone talking with local leaders about how to prevent attacks.

It’s impossible to ignore a disturbing rise in antisemitism across Michigan. This threat comes in the same week that a community in Livingston County heard from the @ADL on how to protect themselves after hateful messages were sent to, in this case, non-Jewish residents.

The rabbis of our East Lansing & Lansing synagogues are leading their congregations with steady hands, and the mayor & local law enforcement have jumped into action to ensure the community feels safe.

Once again, antisemitism & extremism have reared their head in MI & the 7th district. Thanks to the dedicated law enforcement, FBI, & U.S. attorneys who used some complex investigative work to identify and arrest this man before this threat cost lives. https://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/local/michigan/2023/06/16/up-man-seann-pietila-vowed-mass-killing-at-east-lansing-synagogue-fbi-says/70331707007/

#OTD 52 years ago, President Nixon started a violent campaign against Black and brown communities known as the War on Drugs.

@RepBonnie & I are proud to soon reintroduce the Drug Policy Reform Act to decriminalize drug possession, expunge records, & finally end the War on Drugs.

We must transform the system to invest in our communities, NOT criminalize them.

Grateful to have my sister-in-service @Ilhan, a relentless advocate for this comprehensive investigation by the Department.

As with Ferguson, Louisville, and Cleveland, Black people in Minneapolis have long known about these abuses because they've been subjected to them.

This was never about one police department—it's about a corrupt and violent system that continues to target Black people.

The @DOJgov must pursue a comprehensive consent decree rooted in changing policing systems in partnership with the people of Minneapolis.

They must review and disclose whether its funding practices contributed to this harm against Minneapolitans.

George Floyd's life was stolen from him.
